q: What is a CEA test used for?
a: A CEA test is used to check how well treatment is working in certain types of cancer, particularly bowel cancer.

q: What are carcinoembryonic antigens (CEA)?
a: Carcinoembryonic antigens are proteins produced by some types of cancer.

q: Why does the body produce antibodies in response to carcinoembryonic antigens?
a: The body produces antibodies to help fight carcinoembryonic antigens.

q: When is a CEA test usually carried out?
a: A CEA test is often carried out after surgery to check carcinoembryonic antigen levels.

q: In addition to bowel cancer, what other types of cancer can be assessed using a CEA test?
a: CEA tests can be used to assess other types of cancer, including lung cancer, breast cancer, liver cancer, pancreatic cancer, stomach cancer, and ovarian cancer.

q: Can CEA levels also be raised in non-cancerous conditions?
a: Yes, CEA levels may also be raised in non-cancerous conditions such as liver disease and inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis).

q: Where can I find more information about a CEA test?
a: You can find more information about a CEA test on Lab Tests Online-UK.
